climbs.name: Steak Sauce
climbs.fa: FFA TR Pete Cleveland, FFA Lead Rich Bechler, Steve Sangdahl, Dale Moir 1982

content.description:
A classic and fabled roof problem that probably gives no favors to shorter or taller climbers. The free climbing of this former aid route was unlocked by local legend Pete C. on TR a long time ago... The first bold leads of the line came from influential DLFAers Rich Bechler and Steve Sangdahl.

 Start at a seam below the obvious roof with a crack running through it. Thin moves will take you to a small bulge and a large hollow flake. The thing is pretty solid though, and on lead you are sticking wires in behind it. Some big moves through the roof to the jug is the crux boulder problem, and holding the swing was the most terrifying part on lead. if you blow it here you will get hurt no questions asked.
content.protection: At least its a light rack! small wires, small cams, and a couple hand sized pieces for the top.

content.description:
This is the chimney that's tucked in behind the Great Tower on the south side. There are many harder options you can climb, but to keep it at about 5.2 start in the right corner at the bottom and once you get almost up to the wide chimney and keyhole, step left and go up easier holds. The wide chimney itself is a good climb but harder than 5.2.

 (This is #20 in S/M, and is also named South Chimney in Knower)
content.protection: Bring a pair of #3 cams for the initial crack (crux) and some double-length slings for chockstones/trees further up.
content.location: Approaching from below, go around the south (left) side of Great Tower and look at the back side. You'll see an inside corner and crack that leads up to a wide chimney. If you're standing in the right spot you'll see a keyhole at the back of the chimney where you can see all the way thru to the north.

content.description: Smoooth Bush has a couple of bush/tree traverses.  Climb corner to overhang, then crack to the top.

Climb the face left of the corner to the ledge, then exit the ledge left of the roof and climb that face to top platform. 

 Start on easy holds left of the tree, then step right to near the corner. (A direct start straight up from the base of the tree goes harder than 5.8) Then climb left of the corner to the large roof-covered ledge. Move to the left side of the ledge and then step out onto the face left of the roof. A mini-traverse left will lead you to some 5.8 holds that will take you up to the top platform. Just don't go so far to the left that you end up on Cracker Barrel.
content.location: Approaching from below, go around the right (NE) side of Sun Top Tower and you will find the right side of the Great Tower which is missing a big chunk of rock half way up the right edge.

content.description: Tricky pro on this one but easier than Garden Path.
Not so much a chimney climb as a climb in the back of a huge chimney.  A fun scramble.
content.location: On the North side of Great Tower.

content.description: This is a variation to Smooth Bush.  Climb that route until you pass the lower tier of the big roof on the right side, and continue to the level of the highest and largest roof between Smooth Bush and Steak Sauce.  Once there, locate a system of juggy holds that allows you to traverse left along the lip of the roof until you reach the widest part of the roof, at a corner.  From here, mantel onto the face and continue on easy ground to the top.
content.location: This is on the east face of the Great Tower.

content.description: The crux is past the lower overhang.
content.protection: Pro up to 2".  The lower section may not be easy to protect.
content.location: This route is a variation of Garden Path.  It has the same start as Garden path.  Climb up to over hang.  After passing overhang stay on corner to top.

content.description: The lower half is classic Devils Lake. The holds are all there, you just have to figure out how to use them!  The upper half is a fun romp up a nose.  An alternate finish steps right and goes up the steep crack on the N face.
content.protection: None, really, until past the crux.
content.location: On the mossy wall to the right of "North Chimney".  Start on good holds in the middle of this wall.  The route stays to the left of the wall's right-hand edge.  Ends on the blocks to the West of Great Tower proper.

content.description:
The first problem is squeezing in behind the twin pine trees and making your first move off the ground in that cramped space. There's actually two chimneys stacked on top of each other separated by a narrow slit that you have to climb around to get from the lower chimney to the upper one (minor crux). The bottom chimney is easy stemming using obvious features. The upper chimney is more awkward with fewer features for stemming. Finish at the level of Cracker Barrel or continue up and finish right of Greatness.

 (This is a named climb in Knower and is #15 in S/M.)
content.location: From the saddle between Great Tower and Sun-top Tower, look for the obvious chimney protected by twin pine trees.

content.description: Intricate and delicate face climbing.  Start up the thin crack.  Where the holds peter out, step right into the chimney (5.7), then back onto the face or figure out how to lever a very long reach (5.9 or 5.10?).  At the small tree, continue straight up.
content.protection: Mostly thin gear in the crux down low, 1/4-1/2 inch.
content.location: From the saddle between Great Tower and Sun-top Tower, head up the thin crack just left of a chimney.

content.description: A climb from the Old School.  Muscle your way up the wide crack (a couple of fist jams help).  Above the ledge, reach just around the right corner for a fingery layback/sidepull.
content.protection: Fist sized gear low, manky small gear up high.  This route sports two ancient pins.  The upper one would have to be replaced for this to be a well-protected lead, I think.
content.location: Wide crack up the North fin of Great Tower.

content.description: Great Crack is a nice long climb on Great Tower in the Prospect Point Towers formation.  Start on low angle easy rock and climb up to a nice ledge.  From the ledge head left up inside corner.  Do a tough layback in the corner crack and pull up to another good ledge.  Follow the path of least resistance to the top.

This is a nice route but the gear is a little funky(Hard to place WELL) 

  But it has...Great location, Beautiful Views, & Sweet Climbing. What more could you want?
content.protection:
Placing gear before the roof creates a LOT of drag... 

  ~SO~ 

  Be creative with your runners or go no gear till you get past the overhang

content.description: A fun climb in two parts:  the lower dihedral, and the upper face.  The upper part is a little harder (5.8) if you stay by your gear, a little easier (5.7) if you traverse out to the right toward the nose.
content.protection: Better than it looks, but very specific on the upper face.  Take small to medium nuts (1/4-1/2 inch) and a small (~1/4 inch) cam.
content.location:
From the saddle connecting Great Tower and Sun-top Tower, scramble down to the north.  Alternatively walk up from Sun-top. 

  Descend by downclimbing the back (West).

content.description: The Great Tower is a excellent spot for many reasons.  For one, it's close to Cleos Amphitheater. For two, it has lots of easy to moderate climbs, and for three it's in sun most of the day.
